content.raw:
Its fine to use "/" in this context, because Windows supports "/" (for example, when parsing #include statements in C++ files) . Using a path separator is only necessary if you want to show paths to the user.

We should also avoid using boost whenever possible (and use a double wrapper around it when we have to).
content.html:
Its fine to use "/" in this context, because Windows supports "/" (for example, when parsing #include statements in C++ files) . Using a path separator is only necessary if you want to show paths to the user.

We should also avoid using boost whenever possible (and use a double wrapper around it when we have to).

pullrequest.title: SVG support for arcs, disjoints paths and their triangulation / extrusion

content.raw: That is correct. We originally designed the imported to map SVG paths to SDF polylines. But that doesn't work with the svg files that are produced by the dxf exporter that SRI wants to use (like chassis.svg, where contours are made of independent line segments). Since we also want to keep the original SDF polyline behavior, the SVG importer now creates SDF polylines automagically.
content.html: That is correct. We originally designed the imported to map SVG paths to SDF polylines. But that doesn't work with the svg files that are produced by the dxf exporter that SRI wants to use (like chassis.svg, where contours are made of independent line segments). Since we also want to keep the original SDF polyline behavior, the SVG importer now creates SDF polylines automagically.

pullrequest.title: SVG support for arcs, disjoints paths and their triangulation / extrusion

content.raw: I'd just like to point out there's currently an inconsistency of behaviour between SVG extrusion and polyline SDF description. Polylines are closed automatically if the last point doesn't match the first one, but the same doesn't happen for SVGs, where open paths are just ignored.
content.html: I'd just like to point out there's currently an inconsistency of behaviour between SVG extrusion and polyline SDF description. Polylines are closed automatically if the last point doesn't match the first one, but the same doesn't happen for SVGs, where open paths are just ignored.

content.html:
For portability, it's nice to use boost::filesystem with the / operator instead of using "/" characters. See examples_build.cc for an example.

  boost::filesystem::path filePath = std::string(PROJECT_SOURCE_PATH);
  path /= std::string("test");
  path /= std::string("data");
  path /= std::string("svg");
  path /= std::string("arc_circle.svg");

content.raw:
That's easy. Just use my checklist:

* do the RAII thing (big ctors and dtors make for less preconditions checking in methods).
* don't violate the liskov substitution principle
* methods (especially in the public interface) should be callable from any state, once your object is initialized
* make sure that object is always left in a correct state after a method call, even when exception is thrown
* always make querying methods separate from methods that change the state
* Prefer references to pointers, unless NULL is a valid value.
* Answer the following question: If its only done in one place, why is it in a separate method?
* Give up. Object Oriented is just a style, it doesn't help us make better programs.
content.html:
That's easy. Just use my checklist:

  • do the RAII thing (big ctors and dtors make for less preconditions checking in methods).
  • don't violate the liskov substitution principle
  • methods (especially in the public interface) should be callable from any state, once your object is initialized
  • make sure that object is always left in a correct state after a method call, even when exception is thrown
  • always make querying methods separate from methods that change the state
  • Prefer references to pointers, unless NULL is a valid value.
  • Answer the following question: If its only done in one place, why is it in a separate method?
  • Give up. Object Oriented is just a style, it doesn't help us make better programs.

content.raw: That should go into ignition::math. I'm actually using the square of the distance here, because length requires a square root and square roots are not efficient. Vector2 already has a == operator, but the tolerance is not adjustable.

pullrequest.title: SVG support for arcs, disjoints paths and their triangulation / extrusion

content.raw:
We've discussed the issue during the Mentor2 meeting and it we think we can keep the polyline behavior intact, but modify how we parse the SVG (instead of creating a polyline per SVG path, we will create closed polylines contours from all the SVG paths). A little more work, but worth it.
Your sdf flag is my second favorite option.
content.html: We've discussed the issue during the Mentor2 meeting and it we think we can keep the polyline behavior intact, but modify how we parse the SVG (instead of creating a polyline per SVG path, we will create closed polylines contours from all the SVG paths). A little more work, but worth it. Your sdf flag is my second favorite option.

pullrequest.title: SVG support for arcs, disjoints paths and their triangulation / extrusion

content.raw:
We did something similar to resolve #494 in [sdformat pull request 83](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/83/sdf-15-add-flag-to-fix-joint-axis-frame-43/diff). In that instance, we made the default value of the flag in sdf 1.4 correspond to the legacy (incorrect) behavior, and the default value in sdf 1.5 correspond to the "correct" behavior. The conversion script from 1.4 to 1.5 was used as well.

So if we add a flag to `sdf/1.5`, it's default value should match the legacy behavior, and using the "correct" behavior will require explicitly setting the flag. We can change the default value when we move to sdf 1.6, though we'll probably wait a while to jump to that, since it's a bit of a hassle to increase the version number.

Does that make sense?
content.html:
We did something similar to resolve #494 in sdformat pull request 83. In that instance, we made the default value of the flag in sdf 1.4 correspond to the legacy (incorrect) behavior, and the default value in sdf 1.5 correspond to the "correct" behavior. The conversion script from 1.4 to 1.5 was used as well.

So if we add a flag to sdf/1.5, it's default value should match the legacy behavior, and using the "correct" behavior will require explicitly setting the flag. We can change the default value when we move to sdf 1.6, though we'll probably wait a while to jump to that, since it's a bit of a hassle to increase the version number.

Does that make sense?

content.raw:
It's true that we are breaking things here, but I am happy to add a new flag:
You are right about breaking things.
It seems that the new behavior is the "correct" one, and should be the new default (otherwise, we'll have to use this flag all the time from now on).
We are only breaking models with open path, existing models with closed paths are OK. I don't know how many models will affected, but I think the number is still relatively small.

What do you think?
content.html:
It's true that we are breaking things here, but I am happy to add a new flag: You are right about breaking things. It seems that the new behavior is the "correct" one, and should be the new default (otherwise, we'll have to use this flag all the time from now on). We are only breaking models with open path, existing models with closed paths are OK. I don't know how many models will affected, but I think the number is still relatively small.

What do you think?

content.html: maybe we could add an sdf flag that switches between the old and new behavior? If it defaulted to the old behavior, then it would allow existing models to keep working.
